comments.commentBody:
You ignore the reason why people cheat.

People cheat because they're forced to perform tasks that disinterest them, in subjects that bore them; or they are required to study them for reasons that they don't accept.

I hated French. No interest in it. No talent for it. Didn't need it. Didn't want it. Didn't matter. I wouldn't have studied it had that decision been left up to me, but it wasn't. I was ordered to do it, on pain of expulsion. Had I been expelled all Hell would have broken out at home. When studying French became so overwhelmingly awful I did everything that I could to lessen the burden. So, occasionally, I cheated. And after I did I hated French even more than before; if such a thing were possible.

On the other hand, I loved electronics. Electronics fascinated me. My eyes were glued to books about that subject. It filled me with wonder. So I never cheated; not once. No need. In fact, it never crossed my mind. It never occurred to me.

Another difference between them: knowledge of French (or another foreign language) was required to graduate and receive a certificate. We were there to earn that certificate. Electronics wasn't even offered, although it was far more practical and useful, because the school's administration wasn't interested and it didn't want to hire anyone to teach it. This illustrates a central problem with institutionalized education: institutional needs take precedence. Student needs are secondary to those of the faculty and administration.

Scott Walker has produced real results here in Wisconsin. It'd be terrific to see a President Walker take on the bloated federal bureaucracy and inefficient public-sector unions like he did in Wisconsin.

Scott Walker for President!

I was planning to make this anyway -- the chickpeas were soaking -- when I found fresh turmeric at my grocer. So I used that instead of the dried. Just chopping the stuff is the best smell! My chickpeas took longer than 2 hours to cook, but I have previous experience with these beans, so I wasn't surprised. I had to add the chard in batches to get it in my Dutch oven. I can't imagine how it could fit in a 12" skillet.
What was the name of that song playing thru a lot of the episode?

Yes it was a tour de force for Margulies who covered the ground from dead pan comedy to sorrow and everything in between. The whole episode was clever and mostly amusing, not least because of the music.

This episode really showed off the wonderful Julianna Margulies at her best. I thought she was mesmerizing in the playing of  this very complex episode. The episode reminded me of several of the mind tripping episodes that Tony Soprano experienced on The Sopranos and that is really high praise for the actress, writers and all the other actors on this show.
Yes I did
I don't recall. Who/What is Morgan?
And a "W" read the other way is an "M", as in Morgan? Not sure if he would do that. So probably Wolves.
Anyone catch "Morgan" as the street name in this episode...is he coming soon??
George Foreman grill. Can make a mean grilled cheese on that thing in like 5 minutes or less

It would be so hard to go back to '' the way things were " ( before the apocalypse and everything they have been through and seen...... I'd never take my Hayes down but I'd enjoy it while I could........ I love the TWD

Of course. But the silly parents, themselves hooked on their smart phones, dare not tell their kids they dont belong ON during class. Nor during break as far as i can see cos all it does is dumb down communication.  I mean really dumb. Maybe in the future when technology improves this will no longer be a problem, but at the moment it is so reductive and moronic. Dont use social, dont blog under your own name. If your enemies have a yik yak, dont have a profile yourself, dont use facebook, stay below the radar, be stealthy, be private, be secretive, be interesting, be smart, be safe.
I'm talking about Margaret Crouch and Jordan Seman, not about threats of violence mentioned later in the article in which cases Yik Yak cooperated with police.

It appears that these 2 misguided cofounders of yik-yak had no clue what they have created. I am afraid that this will end up in trashing several innocent lives. Very unfortunate and unethical indeed.
If you read the article, you can answer your own question.
I'd love to know which greedy venture capital companies funded this startup?  #BeResponsible
Any app that has a lot of positive potential will not hide the identities of people. People should be brave and bold to share their identity along with their smart ideas. #BeResponsible.

Heidi should have 1000 "thumbs up" for what she wrote. Thank you for summing up the issue so simply.
Anyone remember Lord of the Flies?
I am sure Congress would love to ban this, except there is a little thing called the First Amendment.
Slander is slander.  Congress should outlaw this kind of app.  They will eventually have to anyway.
These people have no respect.  They don't belong in college.

The old purpose of college used to be education - not only on academic matters but on character. Apparently this is seen now as too heavy-handed, so the Yik Yakkers run around with impunity, "free speech" as their defense.

"... immediately de-anonymize bullying comments."

That won't really work. From the Yik Yak legal page:
"Yik Yak is an anonymous service – users do not register or create account names – and Yik Yak does not ask its users to provide their real names, mailing addresses, phone numbers, email addresses, or any other identifying information."
http://www.yikyakapp.com/legal/

The solution is easy and obvious: immediately de-anonymize bullying comments. And other yaks that violate a policy of minimal civility. The app developers have complete discretion. They can show what kind of people they are. Are they the decent folks they claim to be? Or are they all about aiding and encouraging vicious, abusive behavior?

A threat made with Yik Yak is no different from one made by telephone. The user who made the threat is responsible. As the article suggests, a Yik Yak user is not truly anonymous. With a court order, Yik Yak must identify the user:

"The app’s privacy policy prevents schools from identifying users without a subpoena, court order or search warrant, or an emergency request from a law-enforcement official with a compelling claim of imminent harm."

" Drivers get no respect form the public or authorities. "

....and that's not likely to change with dumbed-down rules.
Drivers "get" no respect because they have none for the passenger.

This is ridiculous. Knowing how to get around main landmarks should be a basic skill. We're not talking about finding Cherokee Place or Dank Court.

On the other hand, as a former cabbie, I can see why it's hard to find cab drivers: It's a stressful job with unpredictable income. Pay has declined to barely minimum wage (50 years ago, it could support a family; 30 years ago, a single man). Drivers get no respect form the public or authorities. It costs $500 to get a hack license. And Uber's trying to undercut everything.
Cabbies are not worried about knowing the best way to get to their destination or even where it is. After all, they are getting paid $2.50 a mile and $30/hour while they look for it.
Well, there goes the Broome Street and warehouse road secrets!

Been driving in streets of the 5-boroughs for over 10 years as a regular commuter... in my experience, a sense of direction, common sense and sharp memory of the NYC map is far, far superior to a GPS.

In many instances, I will pull up a map and review the traffic pattern (red, green, yellow on Google Maps) and independently plot out the best route without turning on the GPS function.

Google does not always know the best, most efficient or preferred route... usually it's just the one most travelled. It cannot distinguish between the grief of a jaywalker/biker/pedestrian ridden street vs. a deserted backroad vs. a scenic route.... Like driving down Broome St instead of Canal to get to the Holland tunnel, or driving through the warehouse roads in Long Island City to avoid the traffic buildup before the Queensboro bridge.

I learned some of the best backroads and detours from sitting in the backseat of some of NYC's finest, smartest yellow cabbies and followed suit.

Sitting in a taxi as a driver struggles to enter the destination can be a nerve wracking experience.  Traffic mounts up behind the cab (inevitably having lacked curbed space to pull over all the way), horns honking, nerves fraying, tips declining. We need cabbies who know their way around town.  Please, T.L.C., reinstitute at least a basic level of knowledge as a requirement for a hack license.

Why do you want lance in jail? Consider the circumstances and be honest, Senator, we were all part of that lie in big and little ways. Imagine his life since Oprah, could that experience be much worse?

& Get some perspective. The first week of the Iraq war killed, according to 3 credible estimates, over 100,000 innocent people. Israel killed 500 children with its latest Gaza attack. We all are a big part of that, too, yet I don't hear enough Americans calling for the imprisonment of W, Cheney or Netanyahoo.

Lance is not evil and there are tens of thousands of people out there alive because they followed his methods of attacking cancer. All things considered, he's a net societal benefit. Those other guys, still rich, free and unscarred? Not even close.

Why is Bernard Madoff in prison and Lance Armstrong is not?   Did they not both defraud people out of large amounts of money?  He and his enablers should be cellmates with Bernie.   They have much in common.

"... they did not conclude that donations he had made to U.C.I. were bribes, although they chastised U.C.I. for accepting them." Sorry folks but this does not pass anyone's smell test, even if you have the world's worst head cold. Armstrong can only be described in words that are not printable in this newspaper. Not only should he lose every multi-million dollar lawsuit for his lying and fraudulent behavior, but I am wondering what criminal laws he may have violated (RICO?). The fact that the governing body was in on this massive scam lowers cycling to a position somewhere between professional wrestling and professional arm wrestling. Good luck in bringing it back to respectability.
Cow Tongue tastes great! Until of course you realize what it is then not so much...
While i respect your comments, your analogy between your mother serving you cow tongue and Lance Armstrong is misplaced. Mr. Armstrong definitely comes from the other end of the cow.

Lance was the best of his generation. He pushed his training, his team, and, yes his doping. He was an absolute animal on the bike-- I'll never forget the moment he rode into the weeds when Beloki went down in front of him (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gr89ku-K2WU).

He was also mean, deceitful, abetted by his entire industry, and enjoyed every advantage that his competitors did. Perhaps it's poetic justice that the cycling poster boy has become its scapegoat. But the disgust of some comments here! It reminds me of my mom serving us a new meat for dinner. It was great dipped in mustard. Then she told us it was cow tongue and grossed us out so we'd never touch it again. If you don't like doping athletes, better stay away from professional sports.
The man is a liar and a cheater...and you're saying because everyone was allowed to cheat that makes it okay.....GET REAL!

I don't follow your logic when you say you don't condone doping,  but in the next breath say Armstrong shouldn't have been penalized for his doping (and the other many shady efforts he took to conceal it).  Looking the other way is, by definition, condoning the misdeed.  And as most of our parents said when we were kids, it doesn't matter that "everyone was doing it".  It's still wrong.

Once you start down the road of the ends justifying the means you cannot come back.
A very very bad lesson for the world's sports-loving youth.
We all knew kids who cheated to win, but these people need to be exposed and shamed, not promoted.

All cyclists in the same elite group as Armstrong dope.

That means it was a level, (albeit doped,) playing field -- and Armstrong was #1.

The report is actually a partial vindication of Armstrong.

Doping provides only a very small, incremental advantage. Example: if you're output is 94%, it'll boost your output to 97%. But for billions of couch-potatoes in the world, doping won't transform you into superman.

Lance Armstrong was symbol of hope to million of cancer patients. He was a true, living American hero. He didn't need to be torn down the way he was -- in the end it would have been best to leave things as they were.

I do not condone doping nor cheating. But taken in totality, it would have been best for all parties, if no action had been taken against Armstrong.

There are public-figures in finance, law, politics, sports, entertainment, religion, government and medicine all of whom are actively engaged in violations of conduct, law or rules -- yet they maintain their positions.

This doesn't absolve Armstrong, but it does reveal the hypocrisy and the extremely random nature of fate and justice.

Past, present and future, doping and drug-use is still prevalent in the NFL, MLB, NHL and NBA, as well as Professional-Cycling. If athletes want to risk injuring their brains and bodies and long-term health by willing ingesting PED's, etc, then the sports-world should seriously consider making ALL PED's legal, under doctors supervision.
